case_name: Golam Hussain alias Gama v. State

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 1977 of 1973 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution for a writ of habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 1977 of 1973. Under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for issue of a writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

facts.text: Petitioner is an aged ailing man around 74 years old.

anchor.surface_text: the petitioner an aged ailing man around 74, has been under detention since 1973 and, previous to it,

facts.text: Petitioner has been under detention since 1973.

anchor.surface_text: has been under detention since 1973 and, previous to it, had been facing a criminal prosecution which ended

facts.text: Commissioner of Police, Calcutta passed initial detention order dated July 19, 1973 on petitioner Golam Hussain alias Gama under Section 3(1)(a)(ii) read with sub-section (2) of MISA 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Police, Calcutta, passed the initial order of detention dated July 19, 1973 on the petitioner, Golam Hussain alias Gama, under S. 3 1   a   ii  read with sub-section  2  of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971  Act 26 of 1971   hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Grounds of detention were communicated to petitioner on the same day as the detention order.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds which induced the detaining authority to pass the order were companymunicated the same day.

facts.text: On October 8, 1972 at about 22:25 hrs, petitioner along with associates armed with bombs and soda-water bottles created disturbance of public order on Gouri Sankar Lane by hurling bombs at Jiban Paul and his group.

anchor.surface_text: On 8-10-72 at about 22-25 hrs., you along with your associates Achche Lal Show of 1, Manickotolla Bazar Lane, Satya Narayan Jaiswal of 123/2, Acharya Prafulla in Chandra Road, and others, all being armed with bombs, soda- water bottles created a great disturbance of public order on Gouri Sankar Lane in front of premises No. 8 by hurling bombs indiscriminately with a view to attack one Jiban Paul of 8. Gouri Shankar Lane and his group in retaliation to an earlier quarrel that took place with the said Jiban Paul at 8, Gouri Sankar Lane with your associates Satya Narayan Jaiswal and others.

facts.text: The October 8, 1972 incident terrorised the locality and disrupted normal life amounting to disturbance of public order.

anchor.surface_text: The incident terrorised the locality and threw out of gear the numbermal life stream of the residents of the said locality amounting to police orde r.

facts.text: On November 9, 1972 between 04:45 hrs, petitioner along with associates armed with brickbats, soda-water bottles, bombs, poles created disturbance of public order on Gouri Sankar Lane and Abinash Kaviraj Street by hurling objects to overawe Kalipuja organisers.

anchor.surface_text: On 9-11-72 sometimes between 04-45 hrs. you along with your associates Ratish Pradhan alias Laltu of 23/lA, Abinash Kaviraj St., Benode Kr. Jaiswal of 34B, Gulu Ostagar Lane and other all being armed with brickbats, soda-water bottles, bombs poles, created a great disturbance of public order on Gouri Sankar Lane and Abinash Kaviraj Street by hurling soda-water bottles, brickbats indiscriminately with a view to overawe the organisers of the Kalipuja that took place in front of 8 Gowi Sankar Lane and thereby to terrorise the locality.

facts.text: Earlier on November 9, 1972 at about 04:30 hrs, petitioner's associates threw beer bottles at Kalipuja pandal which was protested by local people.

anchor.surface_text: As a result the lights of the above pujab pandals were damaged. This was in sequel to an incident that took place earlier at about 04-30 hrs when your associates Benode Kumar and others threw beer bottles at the Kalipuja pandal at 8, Gouri Sankar Lane, where some females were then dancing, which was then protested by the local people and the organisers of the said puja.

facts.text: Fact of detention communicated to State Government which reported to Central Government.

anchor.surface_text: As required by the statute, the fact of detention was companymunicated to the State Government which in turn reported to the Central Government.

facts.text: Case placed before Advisory Board on August 13, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The case was placed before the Advisory Board on August 13, 1973 and when the representation of the detenu was,

facts.text: Detenu's representation received, considered and negatived by State Government, then forwarded to Advisory Board.

anchor.surface_text: received it was duly companysidered and negatived by the State Government which thereafter made it over to the Advisory Board.

facts.text: Advisory Board advised continuance of detention on September 21, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: After adverting to the facts, the Board advised companytinuance of the detention on September 21, 1973.

facts.text: State Government made consequential order confirming detention on September 28, 1973, communicated to detenu by middle of October 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The companysequential order companyfirming the detention was made by the State Government on September 28, 1973 and companymunicated to the detenu by the middle of October, 1973.

facts.text: Two criminal cases were started in connection with the two incidents constituting grounds of detention.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Mukherjee urged that although two criminal cases were started in companynection with the two incidents companystituting the grounds for the detention,

facts.text: Petitioner's name was not mentioned in the first information reports of the criminal cases.

anchor.surface_text: the petitioners name was number even mentioned in the first information reports, and he was produced before the Magistrate only on July 5, 1973,

facts.text: Petitioner produced before Magistrate on July 5, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: and he was produced before the Magistrate only on July 5, 1973, and so the order based on those accusations was too irrational to be bona fide.

facts.text: Detenu could not be arrested until July 4, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Police who passed the detention order has stated in his affidavit that there were cases companynected with ,he incidents of October 8th and November 9th, but the detenu companyld number be arrested until July 4, 1973.

facts.text: Petitioner discharged by court on July 19, 1973 as no witness dared to depose against him.

anchor.surface_text: The companymissioner admits that the detenu was discharged by the, Court as numberwitness dared to depose against the detenu in open companyrt. According to him the said order of discharge was made on the prayer of the police on July 19, 1973,

facts.text: Order of discharge made on prayer of the police on July 19, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: According to him the said order of discharge was made on the prayer of the police on July 19, 1973, and thereafter the petitioner was Preventively detained.

facts.text: There was a nine-month interval between the 1972 incidents and the July 1973 detention order.

anchor.surface_text: Another submission, equally an exercise in futility, made before us is that there has been a long interval of nine months between the criminal incidents of October and November, 1972 and the detention order of July, 1973.

facts.text: Detention order does not specify a period and is unlimited in duration.

anchor.surface_text: companynsel pressed the poignant circumstance that the ultimate order of Government dated September 28, 1973 merely companyfirms the detention, being unlimited in duration and unspeaking on the terminus ad quem for the incarceration.

facts.text: Court delivered judgment on February 26, 1974 dismissing the petition.

anchor.surface_text: Writ Petit Judgment on 26-2-74.

facts.text: No statutory shortcoming in the time sequence of detention proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: We see numberstatutory shortcoming in the time sequence set out above.
ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 1977 of 1973. Under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for issue of a writ in the nature of habeas companypus.

The Commissioner of Police, Calcutta, passed the initial order of detention dated July 19, 1973 on the petitioner, Golam Hussain alias Gama, under S. 3 1   a   ii  read with sub-section  2  of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971  Act 26 of 1971   hereinafter referred to as the Act .

issues.text: Whether the detention order is mala fide or irrational because the petitioner's name was not in the FIRs, he was produced late before the magistrate, and the order was passed immediately after discharge from criminal prosecution for want of evidence?

anchor.surface_text: Shri Mukherjee urged that although two criminal cases were started in connection with the two incidents constituting the grounds for the detention, the petitioners name was number even mentioned in the first information reports, and he was produced before the Magistrate only on July 5, 1973, and so the order based on those accusations was too irrational to be bona fide.

issues.text: Whether the nine-month interval between the incidents and the detention order snaps the live link required between the grounds and the purpose of detention?

anchor.surface_text: Another submission [...] there has been a long interval of nine months between the criminal incidents of October and November, 1972 and the detention order of July, 1973. [...] there must be a live link between the grounds of criminal activity alleged by the detaining authority

issues.text: Whether the confirmation order of detention is invalid for not specifying the period of detention, in violation of Section 12 of MISA?

issues.text: Whether the acts attributed to the petitioner constitute a disturbance of public order or merely affect an individual?

anchor.surface_text: Shri Chatterjee took up the further position that the detention in the case on hand was founded on prevention of public disorder while the acts imputed to the petitioner ex facie were aimed at a particular person and number the public generally.

arguments.court_reasoning: Preventive detention distinct from punitive; subjective satisfaction not requiring proof beyond reasonable doubt; discharge due to witness fear, not falsity of allegations.

arguments.claim: Petitioner's name was not in FIR but apprehended later based on investigation evidence; could not be arrested until July 4, 1973; discharged because no witness dared depose; detention followed on police prayer.

arguments.court_reasoning: S.12 does not require specifying period; 'such period as it thinks fit' after confirmation; max under S.13; cites Suna Ullah, Dattatraya precedents; not practicable to specify upfront.

arguments.claim: Acts attributed to petitioner aimed at particular persons (Jiban Paul, Kalipuja organisers), not public generally, hence not disturbance of public order.

Lohias l case and other rulings were said to reinforce this stance.

arguments.court_reasoning: Public order determined by nature, circumstances, impact (terrorised locality, disrupted normal life); examples of private target but public impact qualify; cites Lohia.

arguments.claim: Ultimate confirmation order merely confirms detention without specifying duration or end point, poignant circumstance against validity.

arguments.court_reasoning: Integrated with S.12 argument; no requirement to specify; subject to review and max period.

arguments.claim: No statutory shortcoming in time sequence of detention proceedings (communication, Advisory Board, confirmation).

anchor.surface_text: The consequential order confirming the detention was made by the State Government on September 28, 1973 and communicated to the detenu by the middle of October, 1973. We see no statutory shortcoming in the time sequence set out above.

arguments.claim: Preventive detention distinct from criminal prosecution; latter punitive for past, former preventive for future; subjective satisfaction not proof beyond reasonable doubt.

anchor.surface_text: The branch of jurisprudence bearing on prohibitory detention has been crystallised by now and it is no longer a valid contention, that because the accused has been discharged in a criminal case the ground of charge cannot be relied upon by the appropriate authority for passing an order of detention.

arguments.claim: Live link/proximity not mechanical; depends on gravity of acts, gap length, delay reasons; here justified by serious acts, late discovery, witness intimidation.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that there must be a live link between the grounds of criminal activity alleged by the detaining authority and the purpose of detention, namely, inhibition of prejudicial activity of the species specified in the statute. This credible chain is snapped if there is too long and unexplained an interval between the Offending acts and the order of detention.

arguments.claim: Section 12 does not require specification of detention period in confirmation order; harmonious with S.13 max period; government continues 'as it thinks fit' subject to max and review.

anchor.surface_text: We may reproduce the relevant provisions which are of ancient vintage, being wholly or substantially in pari materia with earlier corresponding preventive detention sections. Nor is the position of law canvassed for res integra. Section 12 and 13 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971

arguments.claim: Disturbance of public order even if targeted at individual if nature, circumstances cause terror, disrupt normal life in locality.
Corrigendum substituting 'public order' for 'police order' not communicated to detenu.
arguments.court_reasoning: It is not so and merits no consideration.

arguments.claim: Strict procedural compliance required under Art.21 procedure established by law in preventive detention.

anchor.surface_text: Observance of procedure has been the bastion against wanton assaults on personal liberty over the years. Under our Constitution the only guarantee of personal liberty for a person is that he shall number be deprived of it except in accordance with the procedure established by law.

holdings.text: There is no statutory shortcoming in the time sequence of the detention proceedings including communication of grounds, representation, Advisory Board report, and confirmation order.

anchor.surface_text: The consequential order confirming the detention was made by the State Government on September 28, 1973 and communicated to the detenu by the middle of October, 1973. We see nostatutory shortcoming in the time sequence set out above.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Timeline complies with statutory requirements under MISA for prompt communication, consideration of representation, Advisory Board proceedings, and confirmation.

holdings.text: The detention order is not mala fide or invalid merely because it was passed on the date of the petitioner's discharge from criminal prosecution for want of evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Could such an order be castigated as malafide and oblique resort to the inscrutable order of detention when the prospects in the criminal case became bleak ? This charge has been repudiated by the Commissioner on oath and we are not able to hold with the petitioner that merely because the detaining authority has chosen to pass the order on the discharge of the petitioner by the court for want of evidence, the order is bad in law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Commissioner's affidavit explains late arrest due to investigation and discharge due to witness fear, not falsity; no basis to infer mala fides.

holdings.text: Preventive detention grounds can rely on incidents subject to criminal proceedings ending in discharge, as preventive detention is distinct from punitive criminal law.

anchor.surface_text: The branch of jurisprudence bearing on prohibitory detention has been crystallised by now and it is no longer a valid contention, that because the accused has been discharged in a criminal case the ground of charge cannot be relied upon by the appropriate authority for passing an order of detention. The former relates to the punitive branch of the criminal law and relates to the past commission, the latter to the preventive branch of social defence and protects the community from future injury.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisprudence crystallized; subjective satisfaction does not require proof beyond reasonable doubt; cites M.S. Khan and others.

holdings.text: The nine-month interval between incidents and detention order does not snap the live link required for valid detention.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that there must be a live link between the grounds of criminal activity alleged by the detaining authority and the purpose of detention, namely, inhibition of prejudicial activity of the species specified in the statute. This credible chain is snapped if there is too long and unexplained an interval between the Offending acts and the order of detention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No mechanical proximity test; depends on gravity of bomb-hurling acts, late discovery during investigation, witness intimidation; Commissioner's satisfaction credible.

holdings.text: Confirmation order under Section 12 of MISA is valid even if it does not specify the period of detention.

anchor.surface_text: We may reproduce the relevant provisions which are of ancient vintage, being wholly or substantially in pari materia with earlier corresponding preventive detention sections. Nor is the position of law canvassed for res integra. Section 12 and 13 of the Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 12 allows continuation 'for such period as it thinks fit' post-confirmation, subject to Section 13 maximum; not practicable to specify upfront; cites Suna Ullah, Dattatraya precedents.

holdings.text: The acts attributed to the petitioner, though targeted at individuals, constitute a disturbance of public order due to their nature, circumstances, and impact on the locality.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Public order assessed by act's nature (bombs, bottles), terrorizing locality, disrupting normal life; cites Lohia; not limited to general public aim.

holdings.text: The corrigendum substituting 'public order' for 'police order' in grounds was communicated to the detenu.
Strict observance of procedure established by law under Article 21 is required in preventive detention cases.

anchor.surface_text: Observance of procedure has been the bastion against wanton assaults on personal liberty over the years. Under our Constitution the only guarantee of personal liberty for a person is that he shall not be deprived of it except in accordance with the procedure established by law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: General principle invoked; procedures followed here.

anchor.surface_text: We dismiss the petition.
cannot be relied upon by the appropriate authority for passing an order of detention. The former relates to the punitive branch of the criminal law a

edges.explanation: Holding h2 rejects invalidity claim based on detention order passed on discharge date, addressing part of i1's irrationality/mala fide grounds.

anchor.surface_text: Could such an order be castigated as malafide and oblique resort to the inscrutable order of detention when the prospects in the criminal case became bleak ? This charge has been repudiated by the Commissioner on oath and we are not able to hold with the petitioner that merely because the detaining authority has chosen to pass the order on the discharge of the petitioner by the court for want of evidence, the order is bad in law.
We dismiss the petition.
subject matter of criminal cases which have ended in discharge, therefore, the order of detention is malafide. The basic imperative of proof beyond re

edges.explanation: Holding h3 affirms reliance on discharged criminal incidents for preventive detention grounds, addressing i1's claims tied to lack of evidence and discharge.

anchor.surface_text: The branch of jurisprudence bearing on prohibitory detention has been crystallised by now and it is no longer a valid contention, that because the accused has been discharged in a criminal case the ground of charge cannot be relied upon by the appropriate authority for passing an order of detention. The former relates to the punitive branch of the criminal law and relates to the past commission, the latter to the preventive branch of social defence and protects the community from future injury.
We dismiss the petition.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that there must be a live link between the grounds of criminal activity alleged by the detaining authority and the purpose of detention, namely, inhibition of prejudicial activity of the species specified in the statute. This credible chain is snapped if there is too long and unexplained an interval between the Offending acts and the order of detention.
We dismiss the petition.
